answers.author: Barry Crook
answers.text:
Our efforts are not focused on cutting budgets, but on not spending all of your budget at the end of the year under some kind of "spend it or lose it" fear. So when a department is "under budget" for the year, they get to keep 50% of that as a re-appropriation the next year. Another 15% goes into a "central savings" account, and the remaining 35% returns to fund balance. The department may use it for any purpose that doesn't set up a recurring expense. Central savings are used at the City Manager's discretion. The balance left accumulates and is rolled over each year.

answers.author: Robert Woods
answers.text:
Just an observation on the "spend it or lose it" concern. In my experience this is mostly a myth. 
Internally, the budget allotments set in the departmental budget review process are set months ahead of the final budgets going to council (and employees rushing to spend that last cent). At that point in time the "year-to-date" figures are quite telling as to the burn rate of expenditures. If the rate is resonable in relation to prior years actuals, (especialy 3rd Qtr to 3rd Qtr) then that is evidence that the end of the year budget spend-a-thon isn't really happening.
Many managers often hold back on more discretionary purchases until near the end of the year to make sure that they will have sufficient appropriations. That does not mean that they are not appropriate purchases. 
Buying bulk office supplies at the EOY may mean that additional purchases are not made until late in the subsequest 2nd quarter. The real question is more like "are we carrying excessive inventories?" 
A study of actual purchasing patterns over the course of a year may give you the information as to whether you are truly stopping unnecessary spending, or merely constructing process to combat a problem that might not really exist.

answers.author: Paul Rosen
answers.text:
Michael,
This is something that I've wanted to do for a while, but seems tough to implement based on political sensativity. However, that being said. I think it's a great idea if you can get the backing to do it. The book "The Price of Government" by Osborne and Hutchinson describes this strategy breifly. In it they mention that any savings going back to departments should only be used for one-time projects that will enable them to work even more effeicently and effectively in the future. Good luck.

answers.author: Harry Peacock
answers.text:
Granted I have been retired for 11 years, but in the 30 years I managed cities this problem/issue never appeared.  Good performance budgeting means that you set forth the objectives and activities for the coming year (or two in my case) for each area of the budget and then you do a careful job determining just what it will cost in terms of people and things to accomplish what you set out to do.  Detailed quarterly review sessions of not only what was accomplished to date against the approved budget/performance/accomlishment standards, but how that compares to the money expended lets the City Council know where they are at all times in terms of what they expected would happen over the next twelve months based on the budget they adopted.  
There is no "discretionary" spending.  If any department has a lot of money left over at the end of the year it should be because it was not able to accomplish all it said it could or changed circumstances made that impossible (something which quarterly operations reports should identify in a timely fashion),  Departments shouldn't be rewarded for making what turn out to be poor budget estimates in the proposed budget

answers.author: Eric Johnson
answers.text:
This is a great issue for discussion. There are unanticipated consequences of any approach. My first year in local government (1985), I attended GFOA training. GFOA had a local finance director discuss an incentive program in use in his city. Many years later, interested in such a program, I contacted the community to get long-term results of their program. The initial response was that there had been no such program. I checked my notes, named the individual who had represented the issue, and was subsequently advised that the program had been eliminated shortly after I had heard about it. Departments had learned to game the system – not an unusual consequence in the field of government budgeting. The lesson I think I learned from that experience is that the concept may work as a one-time exercise. Even then, there are challenges that remain. High priorities tend to get appropriations -- anyway. Carrying over funds to be spent on lower priorities could be sending the wrong message. More importantly, bear in mind that some departments have control over expenditures to a greater degree than others. I refrain from describing that as discretionary spending because that is too narrow a view.
I’ve recently learned a different lesson: I competed for a County Manager position in a nearby jurisdiction. In my interviews with county commissioners, I described my intent to consider a county-wide challenge to create recurring savings and to dedicate a portion of the first year’s savings to a one-time bonus for all employees. Employees were facing yet another year without pay increases, the loss of a significant number of positions in recent years, and a mandated contribution to retirement plans. I thought I might avoid budget gimmicks and permanently reduce spending. Since I was not selected, I may refrain from discussing such a strategy in the future until I have actually inked a contract but I like the concept of a team effort over any process that reinforces departmental silos.

answers.author: Kristi Aday
answers.text:
An easy approach - start an employee suggestion program that rewards employees for cost cutting or savings measures. If the savings can be accurately measured, give the employee a percentage. If not, come up with a set amount and/or extras like days off.

author: Michael Mallinoff
text: My city is interested in starting a cost-saving incentive program for our departments. We would like to offer departments who can cut their budgets a certain percentage of that money back for a project of their choosing. Does anyone have a program or policy similar to this in place? We are hoping to glean ideas and specifics from others who have experience with this type of incentive-based cost-saving measure.
title: Cost-Saving Incentive Program
